lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about food in space.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play video in parts. Ask: “What can they eat?” Students answer on mini whiteboards or by ticking images in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Students work in groups to design a “Class Astronaut Menu” with 4–5 foods. They explain their choices using target language, then compare menus to vote on the best one.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can explain why astronauts eat different types of food in space.
supportStrategies: (Science) Ask: “Why can’t they eat bread in space?” Students list foods they think work in space, then compare with video answers.
stretchStrategies: Students work in groups to design a “Class Astronaut Menu” with 4–5 foods. They explain their choices using target language, then compare menus to vote on the best one.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can share their opinions politely and discuss why astronauts eat differently in space.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Group task: “Design an astronaut lunchbox.” What’s inside? Why? Each group shares their ideas and explains their choices.
stretchStrategies: Students work in groups to design a “Class Astronaut Menu” with 4–5 foods. They explain their choices using target language, then compare menus to vote on the best one.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
